It isn’t the phone, but the charger. Certain defects in a phone charger (or any other line operated switchmode power adapter) can result in the output floating at a high voltage relative to earth ground. This is particularly true of cheap knockoff chargers sold at gas stations, convenience stores, etc. The unit can appear to be working just fine (the phone will charge), but if you become part of a path between the phone and earth ground, you can be shocked or electrocuted. The manufacturers of these cheap chargers cut corners on insulation, clearance and creepage limits, and component quality to squeeze the last few pennies of profit out of their product. They don’t bother to submit devices for safety certification, and may even affix fake UL/CSA/CE labels to them.

Perhaps not directly, but it has killed the motivations of billions of people to actively do productive things to improve their lives. Excessive use fills the mind with useless passive content and lulls the intellect into a state of stagnation and atrophy. Cell phone overuse is similar to drifting through life as in a dream, where nothing actually gets done. It also promotes group-think and peer pressure to think according to the latest viral image and video sensation. It is a poor substitute to getting on with the real business of living and making your dreams come true.
